text: Exercise 08: Link Layer Question 1: Collision Avoidance / Detection To reduce ambiguities about which station is sending, 802.11 defines channel sensing to consist of both physical sensing and virtual sensing, as is shown in this depiction of MACA: Figure 1: MACA Physical sensing simply checks the medium to see if there is a valid signal. With virtual sensing, each station keeps a logical record of when the channel is in use by tracking the NAV (Network Allocation Vector). Each frame carries a NAV field that specifies how long the sequence to which the frame belongs will take to complete. Note: The lecture states that nodes only wait after receiving a CTS. Node C reserved a NAV upon receiving a RTS which is the effect of an optimization in the implementation: Upon receiving an RTS the node waits for a potential following CTS finally reserving the whole transmission time if a CTS is received. In practice there are many more optimizations like this. Question 1.1 Can you say something about the distance of the stations from A? Is station C or D closer? Briefly explain.
